lessons.title: Regular Verbs in the Present Tense

text: To form the present tense, drop the -ar, -er, or -ir from the root (or radical) of the inﬁnitive, and add the ending that corresponds to the subject.
The following verbs can be used as models for all regular verbs in the present tense.
notes: the first-person singular yo has the same ending in all three conjugations.
in the -er and -ir verb categories all three third-person singular forms have the same endings.
subject pronouns are usually omitted in Spanish unless they are needed for clarification or emphasis.

lessons.title: When is present tense used?
grammar: Ahora, veo a Anna (Now I see Anna)
Louis llega a la puerta (Louis is arriving at the gate)
Normalmente, compro las frutas en el supermercado (Usually I buyfruit at the supermarket)
Mañana discuto el plan con ustedes en la reunion (Tomorrow I will discuss the plan at the meeting)
Este verano, viajo a Alemania (This summer I am traveling to Germany)
¿Bebes café o tê? (Do you drink coffee or tea?)
¿Abro la puerta? (Shall I open the door?)
¿Compramos la casa? (Shall we buy the house?)
notes: to describe an action happening now. Often, it is translated with the -ing form in English.
to express actions that take place regularly
to describe events that will take place in the near future.
to ask questions, especially regarding permission, opinion, or preference.
Keep in mind the auxiliary verb do in English is not translated. In Spanish, an auxiliary verb is not needed to ask a question.

lessons.title: Other uses of the present tense

text: Cinco mas quince son veinte (Five plus fifteen is twenty.)
En 1969 el primer hombre llega a la luna (The first man gets to the moon in 1969.)
Si llega el tren, salimos (If the train arrives, we leave.)
Sacé la pistola y casi me mata (He pulled out his gun and almost killed me.)

notes: to tell facts considered unquestionable or universal truths.
to describe a past event, making it more vivid (historial present)
to express hypothetical actions introduced by si.
to refer to possible consequences from an action that took place in the past with casi (almost) and por poco (nearly)

lessons.title: One More Use of the Present tense
grammar: Hace tres años que esperamos una respuesta (We have been waiting for an answer for three years.)
Esperamos una respuesta hace tres anõs (We have been waiting for an answer for three years.)
Esperamos una respuesta desde hace tres años (We have been waiting for an answer for three years.)
Cuanto tiempo hace que observas las estrellas?
Desde hace cuanto tiempo observas las estrellas?
notes: to express actions that began in the past and continue in the present (hace + time expression + que + verb)
or: (verb + hace + time expression)
or: (verb + desde hace + time expression)

lessons.title: Irregular Verbs in the Present Tense
notes: Many Spanish verbs do not follow the patterns of the regular verbs you have just studied.
Instead, they change the root (or radical) of the verb, the conjugation endings, or both.
Because they follow different patterns, they are considered irregular verbs.
Since irregular verbs are so commonly used, a good strategy to identify and learn them is to focus on similarities, grouping them into patterns.
